across.text: Provider of social introductions to a smart set possibly
across.explanation: TOASTMASTER(i.e. “provider of social introductions”). “Possibly” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of TO A SMART SET. Nicely played.

across.text: Turning Mossad’s core agents – note about four likely to join up
across.explanation: ASSOCIATIVE(i.e. “likely to join up”). Solution is OSSA (i.e. “Mossad’s core”, i.e. the middle letters of “Mossad”) reversed (indicated by “turning”) and followed by CIA (i.e. “agents”, specifically the Central Intelligence Agency) and TE (i.e. “note” in the sol-fa notation) once wrapped “about” IV (i.e. “four” expressed in Roman numerals), like so: ASSO-CIA-T(IV)E.

across.text: Cut up over doctrine being changed – it’s not helpful
across.explanation: COUNTERPRODUCTIVE(i.e. “not helpful”). “Being changed” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of CUT UP OVER DOCTRINE.

across.text: Put in type of small English ram
across.explanation: SET UP(i.e. “put in”). Solution is S (a recognised abbreviation of “small”) followed by E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”) and TUP (i.e. a “ram”). “Type of” seems redundant phrasing, but I could be missing something.

across.text: Volunteers chess piece for capturing
across.explanation: TAKING(i.e. “capturing”). Solution is TA (i.e. “volunteers”, specifically the Territorial Army) followed by KING (i.e. “chess piece”).

across.text: Large car going back into advanced plant for restorative action?
across.explanation: CAMOMILE(i.e. “plant for restorative action”). Solution is LIMO (i.e. “large car”, short for a limousine) reversed (indicated by “going back”) and placed “into” CAME (i.e. having “advanced”), like so: CAM(OMIL)E.

across.text: Club perhaps losing several seconds cost series
across.explanation: COTERIE(i.e. “club”). Solution is COST SERIES with the Ss removed (indicated by “losing several seconds” – S being a recognised abbreviation of “second”), like so: CO(S)T-(S)ERIE(S) => COT-ERIE.

across.text: Set up the brim of sombrero initially to tease dandy
across.explanation: COCKSCOMB(i.e. “dandy” – Chambers and Oxford offer no real overlap between the two that I can see, however my Collins Concise backs the setter up with “a conceited dandy”). Solution is COCK (i.e. to “set up the brim of”) followed by S (i.e. “sombrero initially”, i.e. the first letter of “sombrero”) and COMB (i.e. “to tease”).

across.text: Allowing girl showy jewellery
across.explanation: ENABLING(i.e. “allowing”). Solution is ENA (i.e. “girl’s” name) followed by BLING (i.e. “showy jewellery”).

across.text: House in Home Counties close to motorway
across.explanation: SEMI(i.e. “house”). Solution is SE (i.e. “Home Counties”, also known as the South East of England) followed by MI (i.e. “motorway”, specifically the M1 with the 1 swapped for its Roman numeral equivalent).

across.text: What can raise lumps needing at first to be covered by clothing
across.explanation: TONGS(i.e. “what can raise [sugar] lumps”). Solution is N (i.e. “needing at first”, i.e. the first letter of “needing”) placed in or “to be covered by” TOGS (slang for “clothing”), like so: TO(N)GS.

across.text: Compelled civil engineer to split crossing
across.explanation: FORCED(i.e. “compelled”). Solution is CE (a recognised abbreviation of “civil engineer”) placed in or “splitting” FORD (i.e. river “crossing”), like so: FOR(CE)D.

across.text: Bigoted and enthusiastic about right in unrewarding time
across.explanation: INTOLERANT(i.e. “bigoted”). Solution is INTO (i.e. “enthusiastic about”) followed by R (a recognised abbreviation of “right”) once placed “in” LEAN (i.e. “unrewarding”), then T (a recognised abbreviation of “time”), like so: INTO-LE(R)AN-T.

across.text: Deplore pay scale for top management?
across.explanation: EXECRATE(i.e. “deplore”). When written as EXEC RATE the solution also satisfies “pay scale for top management”, i.e. executives.

across.text: Property cleaner cries with attic having to be reorganised
across.explanation: CHARACTERISTIC(i.e. attribute or “property”). Solution is CHAR (i.e. a “cleaner”) followed by an anagram (indicated by “to be reorganised”) of CRIES and ATTIC, like so: CHAR-ACTERISTIC.

across.text: Sobriety at business? Some getting drunk
across.explanation: ABSTEMIOUSNESS(i.e. “sobriety”). “Getting drunk” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of AT BUSINESS SOME.

across.text: Lover of the beautiful with a short girl, note
across.explanation: AESTHETE(i.e. “lover of the beautiful”). Solution is A followed by ESTHER (i.e. “girl’s” name) with its last letter removed (indicated by “short”), then TE (i.e. “note”, again in the sol-fa notation), like so: A-ESTHE-TE.

across.text: Ceasing to be home for artist in removal
across.explanation: EXTINCTION(i.e. “ceasing to be”). Solution is EXTRACTION (i.e. “removal”) with the RA (i.e. “artist”, specifically a Royal Academician) swapped “for” IN (i.e. at “home”), like so: EXT(RA)CTION => EXT(IN)CTION.

across.text: Species at this point forms social class
across.explanation: SPHERE(i.e. “social class”). Solution is SP (a recognised abbreviation of “species”) followed by HERE (i.e. “at this point”).

across.text: Gauleiter, losing province after return, secure again
across.explanation: RETIE(i.e. “secure again”). Solution is GAULEITER with the GAUL removed (indicated by “losing province” – Gaul being an ancient province covering modern-day France and a bit more beyond) and the remainder reversed (indicated by “after return”).

across.text: Second person once seen wearing socks in hothouse?
across.explanation: THOU(i.e. “second person one” – first person is I, second person is you, third person is them; “you” in ye olde speak is THOU). The remainder of the clue plays on how THOU can be found in HO(THOU)SE, wrapped within the letters of HOSE (i.e. hosiery or “socks”).

across.text: Means to choose short film
across.explanation: FREE WILL(i.e. “means to choose”). Solution is FREE WILLY (i.e. “film”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “short”).

across.text: George displaying gold helmet piece for auction
across.explanation: AUTOPILOT(i.e. “George”, apparently RAF slang for the device). Solution is AU (chemical symbol of “gold”) followed by TOPI (i.e. a pith “helmet”) and LOT (i.e. “piece for auction”).

across.text: Hedging put back: sound cut by a small volume
across.explanation: EVASION(i.e. “hedging”). Solution is NOISE (i.e. “sound”) wrapped around A and V (i.e. “small volume”, i.e. the recognised abbreviation of “volume”) and all reversed (indicated by “put back”), like so: E(V-A)SION.

across.text: CertainSouth Pacificneeds a change of key
across.explanation: SPECIFIC(i.e. “certain”). Solution is S (a recognised abbreviation of “south”) followed by “PACIFIC” with the A swapped for an E (indicated by “needs a change of [musical] key”), like so: S-P(A)CIFIC => S-P(E)CIFIC.

across.text: Military show inking on skin
across.explanation: TATTOO. Solution satisfies “military show” and “inking on skin”.

across.text: Returning to identify one’s dope
across.explanation: IDIOT(i.e. “dope”). Solution is TO followed by ID (short for “identify”) and I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) all reversed (indicated by “returning”), like so: I-DI-OT.

across.text: Actually, “nymphet” is misused and not in a kind way
across.explanation: UNSYMPATHETICALLY(i.e. “not in a kind way”). “Misused” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of ACTUALLY NYMPHET IS.

across.text: Endlessly prolong situation not having to settle in mitigation
across.explanation: EXTENUATION(i.e. “mitigation”). Solution is EXTEND (i.e. “prolong”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “endlessly”) and the remainder followed by SITUATION once the SIT has been removed (indicated by “not having to settle”), like so: EXTEN-UATION.

across.text: Middle of Kent county, nice and never one inconvenience
across.explanation: ENCUMBRANCE(i.e. “inconvenience”). Solution is EN (i.e. “middle [letters] of Kent”) followed by CUMBRIA (i.e. “county”) and NICE once the Is have been removed (indicated by “never [Roman numeral] one”), like so: EN-CUMBRA-NCE.

down.text: Moment to change direction to start to exploit game
down.explanation: TICK-TACK-TOE(i.e. “game” of noughts and crosses in the US). Solution is TICK (i.e. “moment”) followed by TACK (i.e. “to change direction” in general), then TO and E (i.e. “start to exploit”, i.e. the first letter of “exploit”).

down.text: Millions in NZ city lacking land in a violent rage
down.explanation: AMUCK(i.e. “violent rage”, a variant spelling of amok). Solution is M (a recognised abbreviation of “millions”) placed “in” AUCKLAND (i.e. “NZ city”) once the LAND has been removed (indicated by “lacking land”), like so: A(M)UCK.

down.text: Prolonged muscle contraction set tuna swimming
down.explanation: TETANUS(i.e. “prolonged muscle contraction”). “Swimming” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of SET TUNA.

down.text: Cautious when getting head down and twisted to one side
down.explanation: AWRY(i.e. “twisted to one side”). Solution is WARY (i.e. “cautious”) with the first letter or “head” taken “down” a notch – this being a down clue – like so: (W)ARY => A(W)RY.

down.text: A number holding promotion by pub is shabby
down.explanation: THREADBARE(i.e. “shabby”). Solution is THREE (i.e. “a number”) wrapped around or “holding” AD (i.e. “promotion” or advertisement) and BAR (i.e. “pub”), like so: THRE(AD-BAR)E.

down.text: He led operation to scramble communication device
down.explanation: RADIOTELEPHONE(i.e. “communication device” working over radio waves). “Scramble” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of HE LED OPERATION.

down.text: Knife found in dried up sea is kept for the record
down.explanation: ARCHIVAL(i.e. “kept for the record”). Solution is CHIV (i.e. “knife”) placed “in” ARAL (i.e. “dried up sea” between Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan – a new one on me, but interesting given this particular sea began shrinking in the 1960s and was all but gone by the 2010s), like so: AR(CHIV)AL.

down.text: Succeeded with fish spear
down.explanation: SPIKE(i.e. “spear”). Solution is S (a recognised abbreviation of “succeeded”) followed by PIKE (i.e. “fish”).

down.text: High point of belief about church held by Poles
down.explanation: CRESCENDO(i.e. “high point”). Solution is CREDO (i.e. “belief”) wrapped “about” CE (i.e. “church”, specifically the Church of England) once this has been placed in or “held by” S and N (i.e. “poles”, specifically recognised abbreviations of south and north respectively), like so: CRE(S(CE)N)DO.

down.text: For instance, radios and televisions can be valuable items
down.explanation: ASSETS(i.e. “valuation items”). Solution is AS (i.e. “for instance”) followed by SETS (i.e. “radios and televisions”).

down.text: I’m talented partner working between government ministries
down.explanation: INTERDEPARTMENTAL(i.e. “between government ministries”). “Working” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of I’M TALENTED PARTNER.

down.text: Dickens is so naff, too
down.explanation: EUPHEMISTIC. A euphemism is a word or phrase used in place of something decidedly worse, so I reckon the clue is playing on how “dickens” and “naff” are euphemisms, respectively another word for the devil and an acronym for – smelling salts at the ready – Not Available for Fucking or Fornication. (Thank you, Chambers.) The clue could therefore be read as “dickens is so; naff, too”.

down.text: Paper coming down on newly-formed union
down.explanation: CONFETTI. Solution pretty much sums up the clue, taking “newly-formed union” to be a wedding. Nicely worked.

down.text: One whose speciality is dialogue in awkward voice translations
down.explanation: CONVERSATIONALIST(i.e. “one whose speciality is dialogue”). “Awkward” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of VOICE TRANSLATIONS. Another nicely worked clue.

down.text: Great folly girl’s built in northern area
down.explanation: LUNACY(i.e. “great folly”). Solution is LUCY (i.e. “girl’s” name – another one) wrapped around or having “built in” N (a recognised abbreviation of “northern”) and A (ditto “area”), like so: LU(N-A)CY.

down.text: Arbitrator set up duty list the same
down.explanation: MEDIATOR(i.e. “arbitrator”). Solution is ROTA (i.e. “duty list”) and IDEM (Latin for “the same”) all reversed (indicated by “set up” – this being a down clue), like so: MEDI-ATOR.

down.text: Policeman dispatched without right equipment endlessly
down.explanation: SERGEANT(i.e. “policeman”). Solution is SENT (i.e. “dispatched”) wrapped around or placed “without” R (a recognised abbreviation of “right”) and GEAR (i.e. “equipment”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “endlessly”), like so: SE(R-GEA)NT.

down.text: What insects can do to mongrel and parrot at home upset
down.explanation: CROSS-POLLINATE(i.e. “what insects can do”, specifically giving plants the sexy times). Solution is CROSS (i.e. “mongrel”) followed by POLL (i.e. a “parrot”), then IN (i.e. “at home”) and ATE (i.e. being “upset”, as in “what’s eating you?” – too loose for my liking within the phrasing of this clue, but then it is a bit of a dog’s dinner anyway).

down.text: The Spanish race has horse coming after ten others
down.explanation: ELEVENTH(i.e. “coming after ten others”). Solution is EL (i.e. “the Spanish”, i.e. the word “the” in Spanish) followed by EVENT (i.e. “race”) and H (i.e. “horse” – both informal names for heroin).

down.text: Excitement on account of European seen around old city
down.explanation: FURORE(i.e. “excitement”). Solution is FOR (i.e. “on account of”) and E (a recognised abbreviation of “European”) all wrapped “around” UR (i.e. an “old city” often used in cryptic crosswords), like so: F(UR)OR-E.

down.text: American put out in a cosy home – eastern spot European husband set up
down.explanation: ANESTHETIZE(i.e. “American put out”, i.e. the American spelling of anaesthetise). Solution is A followed by NEST (i.e. “cosy home”). This is then followed by E (a recognised abbreviation of “eastern”), ZIT (i.e. “spot”), E (a recognised abbreviation of “European”) and H (ditto “husband”) once these have all been reversed (indicated by “set up” – this being a down clue), like so: A-NEST-(H-E-TIZ-E). Bloody hell, I’m fairly inured to Americanisms but even I have to admit this was a proper WTF? when I finally twigged it.

down.text: Choose yttrium component finally in part for battery fluid
down.explanation: ELECTROLYTE(i.e. “battery fluid”). Solution is ELECT (i.e. “choose”) followed by Y (chemical symbol of “yttrium”) and T (i.e. “component finally”, i.e. the last letter of “component”) once these are placed “in” ROLE (i.e. acting “part”), like so: ELECT-ROL(Y-T)E.

down.text: A prized stone set up, literally this, classically?
down.explanation: MEGALITHIC. The solution (kind of) satisfies the clue as a whole, but also comprises A and GEM (i.e. “prized stone”) once these have been reversed (indicated by “set up” – again this being a down clue), followed by LIT (a recognised abbreviation of “literally”) and HIC (i.e. “this, classically”, i.e. the Latin for “this”), like so: (MEG-A)-LIT-HIC.

down.text: Big spider scuttled into rubbish, oddly ugly, note
down.explanation: TARANTULA(i.e. “big spider”). Solution is RAN (i.e. “scuttled”) placed “into” TAT (i.e. “rubbish”) and followed by UL (i.e. “oddly ugly”, i.e. the odd letters ofUGLY), then A (i.e. “[musical] note”), like so: TA(RAN)T-UL-A.

down.text: Cable installers converted Nine Elms
down.explanation: LINESMEN(i.e. “cable installers”). “Converted” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of NINE ELMS.

down.text: Managed cold inside for every reindeer active in winter
down.explanation: PRANCER(i.e. “reindeer active in winter”, pulling Santa’s sleigh). Solution is RAN (i.e. “managed”) and C (a recognised abbreviation of “cold” used on taps) placed “inside” of PER (i.e. “for every”), like so: P(RAN-C)ER.

down.text: Cat family includes the tigers, though two in three are gone
down.explanation: KITTEN(i.e. “cat”). Solution is KIN (i.e. “family”) wrapped around or “including” THE TIGERS once “two in three [letters] are gone”, i.e. (T)HE-(T)IG(E)RS, like so: KI(TTE)N.

down.text: Girl’s not finished eating hot Japanese food
down.explanation: SUSHI(i.e. “Japanese food”). Solution is SUSIE (i.e. “girl’s” name, yet another one) with its last letter removed (indicated by “not finished”) and the remainder wrapped around or “eating” H (a recognised abbreviation of “hot”, also used on taps), like so: SUS(H)I.

down.text: Stock a line in fashionable style
down.explanation: TALON(i.e. “stock” or “cards remaining after the deal”(Chambers)– I have a faint memory of this from a previous Jumbo). Solution is A and L (a recognised abbreviation of “line”) both placed “in” TON (i.e. “fashionable style”, an archaic variant meaning I’ve only ever seen used in cryptic crosswords), like so: T(A-L)ON.

down.text: Staunch supporter
down.explanation: STEM. Solution satisfies to “staunch” or restrict flow, and “supporter”, e.g. for a wineglass.
